stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Memory Scrapper Malware Targets Point-of-Sale (POS) Systems
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On 20 December 2013, malware was submitted for analysis. The submitted file was a memory scrapper specifically designed to target processes named "pos.exe". It monitors "pos.exe" to steal sensitive information from memory, incrementally saving data to %windir%\system32\winxml.dll.
This document incorporates data originally released as US-CERT MIFR-334406.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The submitted file is a memory scraper. This tool is specifically targeted at a process named "pos.exe". In addition, this tool has some networking capability. The malware is capable of enumerating network shares, logging on to a remote network share, moving files between hosts and deleting network shares from the victim host.
When executed, the submitted file performs the following actions on the victim host: The service "POSWDS" is created and started on the victim host. The service is created with the following parameters:
|ServiceName = "POSWDS" |DisplayName = "POSWDS" |DesiredAccess = 0 |ServiceType = SERVICE_WIN32_OWN_PROCESS|SERVICE_INTERACTIVE_PROCESS |StartType = SERVICE_AUTO_START |ErrorControl = SERVICE_ERROR_IGNORE |BinaryPathName = "C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator\Desktop\svchosts.exe" |LoadOrderGroup = NULL |pTagId = NULL |pDependencies = NULL |ServiceStartName = NULL |Password = NULL
The service is started using the following command line and "SW_HIDE" parameter: |CmdLine = "cmd /c net start POSWDS" |ShowState = SW_HIDE
The malware adjusts the following privileges on the victim host: "SeDebugPrivilege" ‐ Allows modification of memory space of running processes.
"SeTcbPrivilege" ‐ Allows a process to assume the identity of any user.
The running processes are enumerated and the process names are parsed for the string "pos.exe".
The malware reads a region of the process memory of "pos.exe" into a buffer. The buffer is then parsed by the malware for specific data. Meaningful data parsed from the memory region is written to the file "c:\WINDOWS\system32\winxml.dll".
